content: The astrolabe was created to meet the needs of astronomers and navigators in the Hellenistic and Islamic worlds who were looking for a more accurate and efficient way to determine the position of celestial bodies. This was important for navigation and for predicting astronomical events, such as eclipses, and determining the times of prayers. The invention of the astrolabe was also likely driven by a desire to better understand the movements of the stars and the structure of the universe, which was a central pursuit of ancient astronomy. The astrolabe provided a new tool for solving these problems and furthering our understanding of the heavens.
